Award.AwardTitle: Geometric Langlands Program and Arithmetic Algebraic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI studies the geometric Langlands program and its applications to arithmetic geometry. The PI will investigate the geometry and the cohomology of the special fibers of Shimura varieties by applying method coming from geometric representation theory, and investigate the possible relations between the characters appearing in the cohomology and the hypothetical 'character sheaves' for p-adic groups. The PI will also explore the possible relation between geometric Langlands program in positive characteristic and the mod p Langlands program.

The Langlands Program is among the most important mathematical frameworks of our time. It is an attempt to unify many different areas of mathematics, such as representation theory and number theory. The traditional arithmetic Langlands program, which is directly related to numbers, has developed more than fifty years and the early development has found significant applications in solving classical diophantine equations (e.g. Fermat's last theorem). The geometric Langlands program, which is a relatively new, is under rapid development, thanks to powerful tools from algebraic geometry. The two parts of the Langlands program share a lot of similarities and techniques, while there seems no direct connection between them before. The PI will try to make some direct connections between them and try to apply some geometric methods to study some more arithmetic problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Langlands Program is among the most important mathematical frameworks of our time. It is an attempt to unify many different areas of mathematics, such as representation theory and number theory. The traditional arithmetic Langlands program, which is directly related to numbers, has developed more than fifty years and the early development has found significant applications in solving classical diophantine equations (e.g. Fermat’s last theorem). The geometric Langlands program, which is a relatively new, is under rapid development, thanks to powerful tools from algebraic geometry. The two parts of the Langlands program share a lot of similarities and techniques, while there seems very few direct connection between them before. The PI's work also makes some direct connections between them and applies some geometric methods to study some more arithmetic problems, like the mod p and p-adic geometry of Shimura varieties. On the other hand, these new connections also shed lights on the geometric Langlands program itself and allow the PI to establish new fundamental results in the geometric Langlands program.

 

The PI's research involves the interaction with mathematical community, in particular with young researchers. The PI taught courses and gave lectures in summer schools that were related to the proposed work, and supervised graduate students and undergraduate students, in projects directly related to the proposed work. The PI also organized workshops and conferences that related the proposed research area. The results of the proposed research are disseminated broadly. They are published in traditional journals as well as on the internet, and are also be presented in the conferences and seminars.
